title: SIL's Language Data Collection
segmentation: Hello everybody, thank you for coming and thank you to the organizers.
I'd like to extend a very sincere thank you to them for inviting me to share with you a bit about SLS data collection.
I've been preparing this talk for quite awhile, a few several months now, and it's been really nice to have that time and feel quite well prepared.
That's an unusual feeling.

But I would you know it's quite a broad topic and I really would like to find what you're interested in and passionate about and what we're interested in passionate about where the intersection of those things lie.
So I hope to invite questions at various points through the talk, not just at the end so that I can respond to questions as we go.
So here's a bit of an outline of the talk I have prepared going to look at the history of data collection from Sio.
Then we'll look at the data that is in the collection.
Look at how you can access the data where that's possible and discuss some possible uses of the data.
Yesterday I was speaking with Michelle.
The originator of like salami, well known to us here and he has kicked me off for the first question.
Which is what is saln?
Why does it seem so mysterious?
So let me try and answer that question to begin with.
I'm.
Silp began was started by William Cameron Townsend.
Now there's a an excellent Wikipedia article that gives you a bit of his life's history and explains the origin of Sils.
He went to first, Guatemala.
And and then to Mexico.

In order to sell Spanish Bibles and discovered that they were not much use because the people didn't speak Spanish, so in 1934 he founded the Summer Institute of Linguistics as a summer school to train linguists in order to translate the Bible into the Cacicol language.
I think it was catchy.
Keller may have got that role.
And since that time, Silv has expanded, and SIL linguists have worked around the world, documenting and analyzing data for hundreds of different languages.
Now over the last 85 years, of course the world has changed dramatically.
Back then, long distance travel was by boat, not plane.
There were no laptops.
There were no phones or certainly no mobile phones or smartphones.
And there was no Internet.
So SL has always worked with the local people and had to adapt to that local situation and to the culture.
And with a history of adapting technology too and also creating technology as it's been needed.

So before the advent of laptops, we just used notebooks and pencils, but they're not ideal for creating dictionary data, because if you write your dictionary in a book, how do you sort the words into alphabetical order?
And what do you do when you need to add 1 in the middle?
It's tricky, so we started using shoeboxes and I have one here.
This is a.
This is quite a modern and modern version of a shoebox.
And the linguist would store their words on 3 by 5 cards.
Well, that's a blank lot.
With these little 3 by 5 cards.
And I gave them some advantages over a simple notebook.
Because you can sort the data, you can add them.
You can throw them away.
You can use a rubber to make corrections.
This box I have had for a few years.
But it wasn't till I was preparing for this talk that I did a little investigation.
About its history and there are some clues on the front.
Here it says, does Derbyshire box 12.
Which isn't a great lot to go on.
But I looked up Dez Derbyshire and I found a really fascinating history.
At least I. I thought it was fascinating.
He big.
I'm working with his karyana in northwestern Brazil.
I believe this is him on the right of the picture.
He spent a total of seven years over 16 years from 1959, working with the local people there.
And Jerry, during his study of his karyana, he discovered that the word order was object verb subject.
During one of his first classes for his PhD studies, he was under the professor Geoffrey Pullum, who had just made a careful study of the claims of object initial languages.
And discovered that none of them stood up to close scrutiny.
So he felt quite confident making the statement no object initial languages exist.
And there's hesitantly raised his hand, and said, Sir, I speak such a language.
It took him a couple of weeks to convince Geoffrey Pullum that it was correct, but the data and his claim were the data was quite solid.
Going back to this particular shoebox.
I was surprised to see the date on the front which says March 2008.
Isn't that a bit scary?
It's like.
Um?
But but I notice that this is one of the later models.
It has a much higher storage capacity than most, and this has been achieved by replacing most of the three by five cards by thin pieces of paper.
So you can get many more words in it than usual.
And as usual, with technological advances, there's a bit of a trade off, so in this case, the higher storage capacity has been achieved at the cost of durability and ease of use.
Just a little aside, some linguists introduced further technological advancement, which was a system of slots and holes in their cards.

We can't really do that with paper, but then they could mark all the verbs and have a slot Noah Hole where the verbs were Sonata slot and slide a knitting needle through to bring up all the verbs in one go.
But they had to be careful not to bring them all the way out, otherwise they have a lot of work re sorting them afterwards.
So there we go.
That's a little story of theirs Derbyshire and shoeboxes.
Another major advancement in technology, of course, were computers.
And one of the first portable computers ever made, 1976.
Kind of astounded.
Was made specifically for language data collection.
This is a photo of it here.
Doctor Joseph Grimes was a linguistics professor at Cornell University and Gary Simons on the left.
Here was his student and Gary was studying both linguistics and computer science.
And they agreed that a computer would be needed for Gary's field work.
So it was built by Bill Hemsath, who was an engineer in the psychology Department on the on the right in this picture.
And the computer he built had this screen screen with five lines of 32 characters each.
It had 16 kilobytes of memory at a substantial cost.
It was thousands of dollars.
And the tape recorder which operated at 300 bits a second.
And Gary and Linda, his wife, used this computer for language survey work in the Solomon Islands and Papua New Guinea in 1976 and seven.
So then Silp began developing programs for computers, and one of the early ones was really based on this idea of a physical shoe box and it was just a digital representation of that.
It was a DOS program.
I don't there was no GUI to begin with.
Just like the shoe box imposed no structure whatsoever on the data, that was entirely up to the linguist.
To decide.
They eventually developed MDF, which was recommended standard of codes, but it was widely ignored or adapted so it didn't end up being all that standard.
So the linguist could set it up any way they like and typically.
It might be like this with your lexeme and part of speech and codes for each of these.
They could set up a completely separate project in.
Shoe box or tool box.
For doing text into linearisation?
But in this case there was no communication between the two, so there's no link between the words in the interlinear text and the lexecon.
Gary Simons was also behind lingual links, which was our first program which structured linguistic data and lexical graphic data with a database.
That was lingual links, which also included a library of texts that were helpful to linguists.
And well, for me anyway, it confused me 'cause I didn't know what it was.
Is it?
Is it a library?
Is it a programmer?
You know groups?
But it was on its way out when I joined Silc.
Fieldworks was released in 2006.
And this program is also based on a database structure and we created a very.
Detailed model of language.
With hundreds of different fields for.
Different parts of you know the academic data that a linguist may create or discover as they.
Um, investigating new language so we have areas for storing phonetics and phonology and orthography and synonyms and antonyms and relations, and even discourse analysis.
We had to.
This is standard sort of screen.
For a lexical.
Entry.
With the.
List of words and affix ISM lexemes in the middle and on the right hand side date.
Details about one of them that selected.
Fieldworks was developed from the outset with the idea of keeping the data and the presentation separate.
So the user can create several views of the data for different audiences.
And this would be an example.
Maybe of this is the same data shown again in a publication view you've got there.
It's for an academic audience.
Maybe it has all the ethics is in the parts of speech.
Some have example sentence is.
And losses or definitions?
This is another view with just the same data, maybe for a child's dictionary.
It's essentially just a list of words and glosses.
Now, because the structure is fixed, the linguists can't make up their own tools so easily in field works.
So we have a tool for doing.
Come into linearisation.
This is linked to the dictionary to the lexical entries, and there are a couple of pauses built in.
So if you've put all of the right slots in place, it's quite complicated setting it up.
But once it's set up, it can be a real, very great assistance to doing into linearisation.
More recently.
We incorporated a collaboration feature so you can send your data to a central server.
Called language Depot typically and then other people can grab that data who are part of your Language Depot team and they can work on the same data and you do a send receive it's.
It's not like Google Docs which is automatically real time collaboration.
It's asynchronous collaboration.
And finally, this data model we have created for fieldworks.
We've extracted more recently from Fieldworks and made it as a separate component so that several different programs can use it and language forge, which will look at next, is one of those.
So language Forge is a web app.
It's rather simpler than fieldworks, but it uses the same underlying database, so not all of the fields that are available in fieldworks can be accessed or edited in language Forge.
But because it's using the same underlying database, it can link to language Depot and you can have different people in your team working on two programs accessing and modifying the same data.
Lastly
As I said this last little bit of History dictionary app Builder.
Takes X HTML exported from fieldworks and turns it into a dictionary app for your Android phone or your iOS phone.
You need a Mac and Xcode in order to make iOS apps, so if you're using Windows or Linux, you can only make Android apps.
So there we go.

That's a quick overview of 85 years of both software development and a bit of language data collection from SL, and I would just like to invite questions at this time before we move on to the data that we've collected.
Motivation was to translate the Bible OK, and that wasn't because that was a very very long time ago.
And what's what is the motivation today?
I mean, is your motivation still to translate the Bible into as many languages as possible?
Is that your personal motivation?
Or yes, is the short answer.
I would say yeah.
Um?
But I would say it's also not the only motivation, so I think we personally I see language documentation as being valuable.
I I see the the the social impact or the change in the SoC that can happen that can come through language development and through Bible translation.
So so yes, I think yes is the is the basic answer and actually that comes through when we start looking at the data.
Probably the data that we have that is in the best shape is the Bible translations, but now it gets a bit complicated 'cause Silp doesn't publish Bibles, but we do hold the Copyright often.
But not always.
But great question.
Any others any others?
It seems that not here OK?
I'm.

Community I would say an on the other side.

summarization_data.sent: Hello everybody, thank you for coming and thank you to the organizers.
I'd like to extend a very sincere thank you to them for inviting me to share with you a bit about SLS data collection.
I've been preparing this talk for quite awhile, a few several months now, and it's been really nice to have that time and feel quite well prepared.
That's an unusual feeling.

But I would you know it's quite a broad topic and I really would like to find what you're interested in and passionate about and what we're interested in passionate about where the intersection of those things lie.
So I hope to invite questions at various points through the talk, not just at the end so that I can respond to questions as we go.
So here's a bit of an outline of the talk I have prepared going to look at the history of data collection from Sio.
Then we'll look at the data that is in the collection.
Look at how you can access the data where that's possible and discuss some possible uses of the data.
Yesterday I was speaking with Michelle.
The originator of like salami, well known to us here and he has kicked me off for the first question.
Which is what is saln?
Why does it seem so mysterious?
So let me try and answer that question to begin with.
